summary: This document is a chain of emails between FBI personnel and U.S. Attorney's Office contractors regarding the transfer and processing of digital evidence from Epstein-related search warrants. It details logistical challenges, data volume (approx. 350 GB export), and the need to get evidence into a usable format for discovery and taint review. This document is a chain of emails from February to April 2020 between FBI personnel and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, discussing logistical challenges and coordination issues regarding the forensic examination and data transfer of electronic devices seized from Jeffrey Epstein's residences in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands. It highlights difficulties in tracking and processing over a million documents.

persons.name: M, I. (NY) (FBI)
persons.role: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.context: FBI forensic examiner coordinating the transfer of digital evidence from Epstein search warrants to the U.S. Attorney's Office, discussing technical details and timelines.

persons.name: M, (USANYS) [Contractor]
persons.context: Contractor for the U.S. Attorney's Office receiving and processing the digital evidence, coordinating logistics for data transfer.

persons.name: (USANYS)
persons.role: Assistant U.S. Attorney or Legal Staff
persons.context: U.S. Attorney's Office staff member corresponding about the status of evidence processing, discovery needs, and legal requirements.

connections.description: Working together to transfer and process digital evidence from Epstein search warrants for legal discovery.
FBI examiner providing updates and evidence to the U.S. Attorney's Office for prosecution purposes.
Contractor working for the U.S. Attorney's Office to handle digital evidence processing.

events.title: Hard Drive Transfer Initiated
events.description: FBI informs contractor that the hard drive with Epstein search warrant data will begin its journey to them.

events.title: Data Export Readiness Notification
events.description: FBI reports that most evidence is ready for export, totaling about 350 GB, and includes devices from New York and USVI searches.

events.title: Timeline Update Due to Staffing
events.description: FBI examiner updates that staffing issues and technical challenges (APFS Macs from the Island) are causing delays in evidence processing.

events.title: Methodology Disagreement Clarified
events.description: FBI examiner clarifies that the U.S. Attorney's Office's insistence on using Relativity for taint review has added months of work and that forensic tools are needed for complete data analysis.

events.title: Coordination call scheduled
events.description: Email exchange scheduling a conference call for April 8, 2020, to discuss issues with the Epstein search warrant data processing and transfer.

events.title: Data review problems reported
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office reports significant problems reviewing over 1 million documents received, including inability to link emails with attachments and mismatched control numbers between load files and native files.

events.title: Request for detailed device spreadsheet
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office requests a detailed spreadsheet tracking each device seized, its processing status, and what data has been transferred to facilitate review.

events.title: Confusion over received data
events.description: An email expresses confusion over which data on a received hard drive is new versus previously received Epstein search warrant materials, highlighting a lack of tracking system.

locations: One Saint Andrews (address mentioned for data delivery)
US Virgin Islands (referred to as 'the Island')
keyFacts: The digital evidence from Epstein search warrants included data from New York and U.S. Virgin Islands (USVI) seizures, with a total export size of about 350 GB.
Evidence included a wide range of devices: Macs, Windows computers, iPhones, iPads, DVRs, servers, cameras, thumb drives, and SD cards.

There was a significant methodological disagreement: the U.S. Attorney's Office wanted data in Relativity for taint review, while the FBI examiner argued forensic tools were necessary to capture all data (like free space and system files).

Processing was delayed due to staffing reductions (down to one day a week at one point), technical challenges with newer Mac APFS formats, and the COVID-19 pandemic impacting work-from-home logistics.
The correspondence shows ongoing coordination in mid-2020 to get evidence into a usable format for discovery to defense counsel, indicating the active post-arrest investigation phase.
The FBI seized numerous electronic devices from Jeffrey Epstein's residences in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands, including computers, hard drives, thumb drives, CDs, and servers.

The U.S. Attorney's Office was struggling to review over 1 million documents due to severe technical issues: emails could not be linked to attachments, and load file control numbers did not match native files.
A major point of contention was the lack of a clear inventory or tracking system for the seized devices and the data extracted from them, causing confusion and delays.
The correspondence reveals internal coordination challenges between the FBI's forensic examiners and the prosecutors, exacerbated by network upgrades and remote work in early 2020.
